questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia is suggestive of niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Vitamin B3 (also called niacin, nicotinic acid)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1/Thiamine deficiency: can manifest as wet beriberi (CVS features like heart failure and edema), dry beriberi (peripheral neuritis), or as Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis (in alcoholics). Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6/Pyridoxine deficiency: causes Convulsions, hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy (deficiency inducible by isoniazid and oral contraceptives), sideroblastic anemia (due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis and iron excess)

 

Option D. Vitamin B12/Cobalamin deficiency: causes Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia, paraesthesia and subacute combined degeneration due to abnormal myelin. Associated with

↑ serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, along with 2° folate deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

 

A high tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (isthmus lies against II, III and IV tracheal rings). It violates the first ring of trachea. Tracheostomy at this site can cause perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis and is always avoided.

 

Only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx because in such cases, the total larynx anyway would ultimately be removed and a fresh tracheostome made in a clean area lower down.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy - Not an indication for high tracheostomy as it does not necessitate altering the anatomy at the level of the isthmus or above.

 

Option B. Tracheomalacia - This condition, characterized by a weakness of the tracheal support cartilage, does not require a high tracheostomy. Treatment usually involves support lower in the trachea.

 

Option C. Foreign body obstruction - Removal of a foreign body typically does not require a high tracheostomy. This procedure would be too high to effectively clear an obstruction that is likely situated lower in the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High tracheostomy is specifically indicated for suspicion of laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery, as this condition requires eventual removal of the larynx, allowing for the creation of a fresh tracheostome in a new, clean area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 359

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radkowski

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects adolescent males. The staging system specifically related to JNA is the Radkowski staging system. This system helps to classify the extent of the tumor based on its location and spread:

 

  • Stage I: Tumor confined to the nasopharynx, nasal cavity, and may involve the paranasal sinuses.
  • Stage II: Tumor extends into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Stage III: Tumor invades the infratemporal fossa.
  • Stage IV: Tumor extends to the intracranial space, including the foramen magnum.

 

The Radkowski staging system helps in determining the surgical approach and prognosis for patients with JNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for various carcinomas, especially solid tumors like those in breast cancer, lung cancer, etc. It stands for Tumor, Node, Metastasis.

 

Option B. Ann Arbor: The Ann Arbor staging system is used for lymphomas, particularly Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

 

Option D. Dukes: The Dukes staging system is used for colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.

 

Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Relative risk 

 

The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

 

 

Interpretation of RR

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attributable risk (AR):  is the difference in the risk of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, and represents the proportion of disease that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

Option B. Odds ratio (OR):  is the ratio of the odds of disease in the exposed group to the odds of disease in the non-exposed group.

 

Option D. Population attributable risk (PAR):  is the proportion of disease cases in the population that can be reduced if risk factor is modified or eliminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor
  • Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR)
  • Strength of association:
    • Relative risk (cohort study)
    • Odds ratio (case control study)

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scala tympani

 

The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the Scala tympani.

 

A cochlear implant works by producing meaningful electrical stimulation of the auditory nerve where degeneration of the hair cells in the cochlea has progressed to a point such that amplification provided by hearing aids is no longer effective.

 

The principle of cochlear implant surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. This allows the electrodes to be in close proximity to the spiral ganglion cells and their dendrites (that lie in the modiolus and osseous spiral lamina of the cochlea, respectively).

 

There are broadly two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation:

 

  1. The facial recess approach where a simple cortical mastoidectomy is done. The facial recess is opened by performing a posterior tympanotomy. The stapes, promontory and round window niche are identified. Cochleostomy is then performed anteroinferior to the round window membrane to a diameter of 1.0 - 1.6 mm depending on the electrode to be used.
  2. The pericanal techniques where a tympanomeatal flap is elevated to perform a cochleostomy either by endaural or postaural approach. In the pericanal techniques a bony tunnel is drilled along the external canal towards the middle ear. The examples of pericanal techniques include the Veria and suprameatal recess approach.

 

The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Round window - Not typically the site for electrode placement in cochlear implants.

 

Option B. Oval window - Also not used for electrode placement; this structure connects the middle ear to the inner ear.

 

Option C. Scala vestibuli - Another perilymph-filled cavity in the cochlea, but not the preferred location for electrode placement due to its anatomy and relation to the auditory pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal auditory nerve stimulation, highlighting the importance of precision in surgical approaches to maximize the benefits of the implant.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is used for which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genome editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is a revolutionary technology used primarily for genome editing. The system allows scientists to alter DNA sequences and modify gene function. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) component is a segment of DNA containing short repetitions of base sequences, and the Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) is an enzyme that can cut DNA at specific locations guided by RNA. This technology enables the precise removal, addition, or alteration of sections of the DNA sequence, which makes it incredibly powerful for correcting genetic defects, studying gene function, and even treating genetic diseases.

 

While CRISPR-Cas9 has potential applications in diagnostics, such as detecting viral infections, its primary and most well-known application is in genome editing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DNA analysis: Although CRISPR technology can be used in some diagnostic contexts, DNA analysis typically refers to techniques like PCR, sequencing, and electrophoresis. CRISPR-Cas9's main function is not analysis but editing.

 

Option C. Determination of chromosomal defects: Chromosomal defects are usually determined through methods like karyotyping or FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization). CRISPR-Cas9 is not used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities but for editing specific gene sequences.

 

Option D. Radiological diagnosis: Radiological diagnosis involves imaging techniques like X-rays, CT scans, and MRIs. CRISPR-Cas9 is unrelated to these imaging methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is a cutting-edge technology used primarily for genome editing, allowing for the precise modification of DNA sequences, which holds great promise for treating genetic disorders and advancing genetic research.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is most heat stable? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (d) Hepatitis B

 

  • Hepatitis B belongs to Group F in the relative heat sensitivity classification, making it the least heat sensitive (most heat stable) vaccine among the given options. 
  • Vaccines are grouped from A to F based on their sensitivity to heat, with Group A being the most heat sensitive and Group F being the least heat sensitive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine): Incorrect OPV is classified in Group A, making it the most heat sensitive vaccine. It appears at the extreme left of the heat sensitivity scale, indicating its high vulnerability to heat degradation. For long-term storage, OPV requires temperatures between -15°C to -25°C.

 

Option B. Measles: Incorrect Measles vaccine falls in Group D of the heat sensitivity classification. As a freeze-dried vaccine, it has moderate heat sensitivity - more stable than OPV but less stable than BCG and Hepatitis B.

 

Option C. BCG: Incorrect BCG vaccine is categorized in Group E of heat sensitivity. While it demonstrates good heat stability and is more stable than both OPV and Measles, it is still more heat sensitive than Hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The heat stability of vaccines follows a distinct hierarchy: Hepatitis B (Group F) → BCG (Group E) → Measles (Group D) → OPV (Group A). 
  • This property significantly impacts cold chain management requirements for each vaccine, with the most heat-sensitive vaccines requiring stricter temperature controls.

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center
Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is found to weigh 8kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) is provided below. Plot the growth chart for this child. What is the most appropriate advice based on the plotted graph? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

 

The WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) shows that the weight of 8 kg for a 16-month-old boy falls between -2 standard deviations (SD) and -3 SD, indicating moderate malnutrition. This suggests that the child is not receiving adequate nutrition and is at risk for growth and developmental delays.

 

In such cases, it is important to educate the mother on proper feeding practices to ensure the child receives a balanced diet with adequate nutrients. This can involve guidance on meal frequency, food variety, and portion sizes to improve the child's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No malnutrition - Assure the mother: This option is incorrect because the child’s weight for height falls between -2SD and -3SD on the growth chart, indicating moderate malnutrition rather than no malnutrition.

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition - home treatment: This option is incorrect as mild malnutrition is indicated when the weight-for-height is between -1SD and -2SD. The child’s weight falls between -2SD and -3SD, indicating moderate malnutrition.

 

Option C. Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center: This option is incorrect because severe malnutrition is diagnosed when the weight-for-height is less than -3SD. The child’s weight does not fall into this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moderate malnutrition in children is indicated by a weight-for-height between -2SD and -3SD on the WHO growth chart, necessitating education on proper feeding practices.

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intrinsic asthma

 

Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is often associated with nasal polyps. This type of asthma does not have an allergic or atopic component and tends to develop in adulthood. Intrinsic asthma is characterized by a non-IgE mediated pathway involving eosinophils and neutrophils, often triggered by non-allergic factors such as viral infections, stress, or exercise. Nasal polyps in this context are linked to chronic inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages, common in non-allergic forms of asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brittle asthma: This is a term used to describe a severe form of asthma where patients experience frequent, severe exacerbations. While serious, it does not specifically correlate with the presence of nasal polyps more than other types of asthma.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Known as allergic asthma, it is mediated by IgE and typically involves allergen triggers like pollen, dust mites, and molds. Nasal polyps are less commonly associated with this subtype compared to intrinsic asthma.

 

Option D. Exercise-induced asthma: This condition, characterized by bronchoconstriction triggered by physical activity, is not typically associated with nasal polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Pulmonology/Asthma/Chap 287

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is preferred in anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar Nerve

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting.
  • By stimulating this nerve, we can observe the twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand, which is representative of deeper muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.
  • The ulnar nerve is easily accessible and provides consistent responses.

 

Why it's preferred:

 

  • Neuromuscular monitoring aims to ensure that patients have adequate muscle paralysis during surgery and complete recovery from paralysis before waking up.
  • The ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle combination has a similar sensitivity to neuromuscular blocking drugs as the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles, which are critical for breathing and airway protection.
  • Using a Train of Four monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator, the ulnar nerve is stimulated to observe the twitch response, allowing anesthesiologists to gauge the depth of neuromuscular blockade and adjust drug dosages accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve is less commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring because it does not provide as consistent or reliable a response as the ulnar nerve. The muscle response to stimulation of the median nerve may not accurately reflect the status of deeper muscles.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve innervates muscles that primarily affect the extension of the wrist and fingers. While it can be used for monitoring, it is not the preferred choice because it is less sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents compared to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Mandibular Nerve: The mandibular nerve is not used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting. It is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and does not provide a useful twitch response for assessing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in anesthesia due to its accessibility and reliable twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle, which reflects the status of critical muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 834

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

Given the description of "Bilateral right sided loss of vision," the most likely site of the lesion would be the  Left optic tract. This type of visual field loss is consistent with the right visual field information being interrupted after the optic chiasma, which would affect the right visual field in both eyes.The optic tracts carry visual information after it has crossed at the optic chiasma. A lesion in the left optic tract would lead to a loss of vision in the right visual field of both eyes (homonymous hemianopia). This is because the left optic tract carries information from the right half of the visual field of each eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Optic Tract: Similarly, a lesion in the right optic tract would cause a loss of vision in the left visual field of both eyes. This is also homonymous hemianopia, but on the opposite side of the visual field loss compared to a left optic tract lesion.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma can cause various types of visual field defects. The most common is bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes. This typically occurs with pituitary tumors that compress the chiasma from below.

 

Option D. Optic Radiation: The optic radiation carries visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex. A lesion in the optic radiation can also lead to homonymous hemianopia. The specific location within the optic radiation (e.g., Meyer's loop) can lead to more specific deficits like a superior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

questions.text: An adolescent male came with complaints of lesions all over the face and back, which were predominantly comedones. What is the most effective treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic doxycycline

 

Acne vulgaris, particularly when it predominantly presents with comedones, is a common condition in adolescents. Comedones are the primary lesions in acne, which can progress to inflammatory lesions if not adequately managed. Systemic doxycycline is an effective treatment for moderate to severe acne, particularly when it involves both comedones and inflammatory lesions like papules and pustules. Doxycycline acts as an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory agent, which helps reduce the bacteria responsible for acne (Propionibacterium acnes) and the inflammation associated with acne lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systemic isotretinoin: Isotretinoin is a powerful systemic retinoid used primarily for severe, nodular cystic acne. Since the question specifies comedones without mention of nodulocystic lesions, systemic isotretinoin is not the most appropriate first-line treatment for this case.

 

Option C. Topical Dapsone: Topical Dapsone is used in the treatment of acne, particularly in inflammatory lesions. However, it may not be as effective for widespread comedones over the face and back, and topical treatments may not be feasible for extensive cases.

 

Option D. Systemic Azithromycin: While azithromycin is an antibiotic that can be used in acne treatment, it is less commonly used compared to doxycycline and is not the first-line treatment for comedonal acne. Doxycycline is preferred due to its broader use and efficacy in managing both comedonal and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic doxycycline is the most effective treatment for moderate to severe acne that involves comedones and inflammatory lesions, particularly when the condition is extensive.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

 

The anti-apoptotic factor among the following is BcI-2.

 

Apoptosis is a process of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a highly regulated process that involves a complex network of proteins and signaling pathways. Among the proteins involved in apoptosis are two families of proteins known as the Bcl-2 family and the caspase family.

 

The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members. The pro-apoptotic members include Bax, Bak, and others, while the anti-apoptotic members include Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, and others. The balance between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family is important in determining whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P-53: P-53 is a tumor suppressor protein known for its role in preventing cancer. It can induce apoptosis but is generally considered a promoter of cell cycle arrest and DNA repair in response to DNA damage, rather than being anti-apoptotic.

 

Option B. K-ras: K-ras is an oncogene that, when mutated, contributes to cancer progression by promoting cellular proliferation and survival, not directly inhibiting apoptosis.

 

Option D. BAK: BAK, like Bax, is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family. It promotes apoptosis by facilitating mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, which is a critical step in the activation of the apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

choices.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done 

 

The preferred treatment for choledochal cysts is not merely opening and draining them, but rather complete surgical removal of the cyst (cyst excision) and reconstruction of the biliary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma: The risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts can be significantly higher than in the general population. Regular monitoring and prophylactic surgical intervention are often recommended to manage this risk.

 

Option C. Todani classification used for grading: The Todani classification is indeed used to categorize choledochal cysts based on their anatomical location and type. This classification helps guide the treatment approach and prognostic assessment, making it fundamental in the management of choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Associated with abnormal biliopancreatic junction: Choledochal cysts are often associated with an abnormal junction of the pancreatic and biliary ducts. This anomaly can lead to pancreatic juices refluxing into the bile duct, increasing the risk of inflammation and subsequent complications like cyst formation and malignancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

questions.text: Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 Weeks

 

Congenital biliary atresia is a condition where the bile ducts are blocked or absent, leading to bile accumulation in the liver. This condition often presents with jaundice that persists beyond the normal neonatal period.

 

This option is correct. If jaundice is present beyond the first 2 weeks of an infant's life, it is a significant indicator to suspect congenital biliary atresia. Early diagnosis is crucial for better outcomes, and any persistent jaundice beyond this period warrants further investigation for possible biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond 2 weeks.

questions.text: Delphian lymph nodes belong to which level in neck nodes? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level 6

 

The Delphian lymph node is a prelaryngeal lymph node located just above the thyroid isthmus. In the classification of neck lymph nodes, it is part of:

 

Also known as the central compartment, Level 6 includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal (Delphian) lymph nodes. This is the correct level for the Delphian lymph node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levels 3-4: These typically refer to the middle and lower jugular lymph nodes, which are located along the mid and lower third of the internal jugular vein.

 

Option B. Levels 1-2: Level 1 includes the submental and submandibular nodes, and Level 2 includes the upper jugular lymph nodes. These are not the locations of the Delphian lymph node.

 

Option C. Level 5: This includes the posterior triangle group of lymph nodes, located along the lower half of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, extending into the supraclavicular fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Delphian lymph node is categorized as Level 6 in the classification of neck lymph nodes, situated in the central compartment above the thyroid isthmus.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented in the below figure by drug X? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epsilon Amino Caproic acid

 

The diagram illustrates the process of fibrinolysis, where plasminogen is converted into plasmin by activators like streptokinase. Plasmin is responsible for breaking down fibrin into fibrin degradation products, effectively dissolving clots. Drug X, as represented in the diagram, inhibits this process, thereby acting as an anti-fibrinolytic agent. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) is an anti-fibrinolytic drug that works by inhibiting the activation of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby preventing the breakdown of fibrin and stabilizing clots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clopidogrel: This is an antiplatelet drug that prevents blood clots by inhibiting platelet aggregation. It does not have any direct role in inhibiting fibrinolysis as shown in the diagram.

 

Option C. Tenecteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent that promotes the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby enhancing fibrinolysis and breaking down clots. It is the opposite of what Drug X does in the diagram.

 

Option D. Aspirin: This is an antiplatelet drug that inhibits the cyclooxygenase enzyme, reducing the formation of thromboxane A2, which is involved in platelet aggregation. Like Clopidogrel, it does not inhibit fibrinolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) is an anti-fibrinolytic drug that inhibits the activation of plasminogen, thereby preventing the breakdown of fibrin and stabilizing blood clots.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

The histological image shows the thymus, a primary lymphoid organ responsible for T-cell maturation. Key features of the thymus seen in the image include:

 

  • Lobular architecture with a cortex (darker staining due to densely packed immature T cells) and a medulla (lighter staining due to less dense mature T cells).
  • Presence of Hassall's corpuscles in the medulla, which are unique to the thymus.
  • Absence of lymphoid follicles, which differentiates it from secondary lymphoid organs like lymph nodes and spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Incorrect. A lymph node has distinct cortical follicles, germinal centers, and a medullary sinus. The image does not show any of these structures, ruling out the lymph node.

 

Option B. Palatine Tonsil: Incorrect. Palatine tonsils contain lymphoid follicles and crypts. Crypts are absent in the given image, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Spleen: Incorrect. The spleen exhibits red pulp (vascular sinusoidal spaces) and white pulp (lymphoid nodules with central arterioles). These features are absent in the image, excluding the spleen as the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is scheduled to receive a kidney transplant from his son who is a compatible donor. What is this type of transplant known as?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Allograft

 

Explanation:

 

An allograft is a transplantation of tissue or an organ from one individual to another of the same species but with different genetic makeup. In this scenario, the kidney transplant from a son to his father is an example of an allograft because they are both human but genetically different individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autograft: An autograft is a transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. Examples include skin grafts taken from one area of the body to treat burns in another area.

 

Option C. Xenograft: A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs from one species to another. This type of transplant is not common in clinical practice due to the high risk of immune rejection and other complications. An example would be a pig heart valve transplanted into a human.

 

Option D. Isograft: An isograft is a transplantation of tissue or organs between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of transplant is also known as a syngeneic transplant and has the advantage of minimal risk of immune rejection due to the genetic identity between the donor and the recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A kidney transplant from a son to his father is classified as an allograft because it involves the transfer of an organ between two genetically different individuals of the same species.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses spreads predominantly through water? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HAV (Hepatitis A Virus)

 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) primarily spreads through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water. It is one of the main viral pathogens that uses water as its predominant transmission route. The virus is highly stable in water and sewage, making waterborne transmission a significant public health concern, especially in areas with poor sanitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HCV (Hepatitis C Virus): Incorrect because HCV spreads predominantly through the parenteral route, particularly through needlestick injuries, blood transfusions, and surgical procedures.

 

Option C. HDV (Hepatitis D Virus): Incorrect because HDV is a dependent virus that requires the presence of HBV for its replication and transmission. It cannot spread independently through water.

 

Option D. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): Incorrect because HBV primarily spreads through vertical transmission (mother to child) in developing countries like India. While sexual transmission is possible, it's relatively rare. It does not spread through water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A virus spreads predominantly through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water, unlike other hepatitis viruses, which have different primary modes of transmission.

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulse rate

 

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to evaluate the severity of traumatic injuries in patients.

 

It takes into account the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate to calculate a score that can predict the likelihood of survival.

 

The score range is 0-12.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale: The GCS is included in the RTS and evaluates the patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option B. Systolic Blood Pressure: SBP is included in the RTS and measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.

 

Option D. Respiratory Rate: RR is included in the RTS and measures the number of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate, but does not include pulse rate.

questions.text: In Menke's disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysyl oxidase

 

Lysyl oxidase is the enzyme affected in Menkes disease. Menkes disease is a genetic disorder that impairs copper absorption and transport, leading to a deficiency of copper-dependent enzymes like lysyl oxidase. Lysyl oxidase is crucial for the cross-linking of collagen and elastin fibers in connective tissues, and its deficiency results in connective tissue abnormalities seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl hydroxylase: Lysyl hydroxylase is not directly affected by Menkes disease. Lysyl hydroxylase is involved in the post-translational modification of collagen, and its dysfunction can lead to certain types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not Menkes disease.

 

Option C. Prolyl oxidase: Prolyl oxidase is not directly associated with Menkes disease. It is involved in the formation of collagen cross-links but is not specifically affected in this condition.

 

Option D. Prolyl hydroxylase: Prolyl hydroxylase is not the enzyme affected by Menkes disease. It plays a role in collagen synthesis, but its deficiency is not a characteristic feature of Menkes disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke’s kinky hair syndrome is an x-linked defect (affects only male child). It is a condition in which dietary copper is absorbed from GI tract; but cannot be transported to blood due to absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene).

 

Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells as well as in other tissue cells. The copper that has entered into the cell is not able to get out of the cells, and so it is accumulated. Hence, copper is not available for metabolism, resulting in defective cross-linking of connective tissue. Vascular and connective tissues are affected, and child dies usually in infancy. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome two years ago now presents with facial edema and proteinuria. What is the most likely finding on their renal biopsy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimal Change Disease

 

Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most likely finding on renal biopsy in this patient with recurrent nephrotic symptoms. MCD frequently follows a relapsing and remitting course. After initial treatment and remission, approximately 70-75% of adults with MCD will experience relapses, characterized by the return of proteinuria and edema. The facial edema mentioned is typical of nephrotic syndrome due to hypoalbuminemia and resultant decreased oncotic pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amyloid Nephropathy: Amyloid nephropathy typically causes a progressive decline in renal function rather than a relapsing-remitting course. It involves deposition of amyloid fibrils (AL or AA type) in glomeruli, leading to proteinuria. However, amyloidosis usually presents with a more indolent, progressive course with multi-system involvement, not the relapsing pattern suggested in this case.

 

Option C. Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by rapid deterioration of renal function over days to weeks, with hematuria, proteinuria, and red cell casts. It typically presents with a nephritic rather than nephrotic picture. The clinical history of previous nephrotic syndrome with relapse after two years is inconsistent with the acute, aggressive nature of RPGN.

 

Option D. Crescentic Glomerulonephritis: Crescentic glomerulonephritis, characterized by the formation of cellular crescents in Bowman's space, represents severe glomerular injury. Like RPGN, it presents with rapidly deteriorating renal function and a primarily nephritic picture, not the recurrent nephrotic presentation described in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Minimal Change Disease should be considered in patients with relapsing nephrotic syndrome, as it characteristically demonstrates a pattern of remissions and relapses over time.

choices.text: Drug interaction between anti-tuberculosis (ATT) drugs and ART

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with both TB and AIDS is started on antiretroviral therapy (ART). Shortly after, he experiences a worsening of symptoms, including fever and malaise. What is the most likely cause of this clinical deterioration? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS)

 

Explanation:

 

IRIS occurs after initiating ART in HIV patients with an underlying opportunistic infection (e.g., TB).

 

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Before ART: Severe immunosuppression limits the immune response against TB
    • After ART initiation: Rapid immune restoration triggers an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing but previously unrecognized TB
    • Result: Clinical worsening with fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms

 

Types of IRIS:

 

  • Paradoxical IRIS: Worsening of TB symptoms despite adequate treatment
  • Unmasking IRIS: New onset TB symptoms after ART initiation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug interaction between ATT and ART: Rifampin reduces ART drug levels, but this does not cause fever and malaise

 

Option B. Resistance to MTB: Would cause persistent infection, not acute worsening

 

Option D. Development of extrapulmonary TB: IRIS can exacerbate existing TB, but it is not a new TB infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) occurs after ART initiation, leading to an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing infections.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-rebreathing mask

 

The oxygen delivery device shown in the image above is a non-rebreathing mask (NRBM).

 

Non-rebreathing mask (NRBM):

  • The non-rebreathing mask provides high concentrations of oxygen. It features a reservoir bag attached to it, which helps in providing a high flow of oxygen.
  • The mask has one-way valves that prevent exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring that only oxygen is inhaled.
  • The maximum FiO2 given by an NRBM is approximately 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: A Venturi mask is designed to deliver a precise oxygen concentration. It has interchangeable valves that regulate the amount of oxygen and ambient air mix, providing specific FiO2 levels. It is typically used when controlled oxygen therapy is required.

 

 

 

Option B. Hudson mask: The Hudson mask, also known as a simple face mask, delivers oxygen concentrations ranging from 40% to 60%. It does not have a reservoir bag and is less precise in delivering a specific oxygen concentration compared to the Venturi mask.

 

 

Option C. Nebulizer mask: A nebulizer mask is used to deliver aerosolized medications (such as bronchodilators) to patients. It is attached to a nebulizer machine, which converts liquid medication into a fine mist for inhalation. This mask is not primarily used for oxygen delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is an oxygen delivery device that provides high concentrations of oxygen, up to approximately 80%, and is characterized by a reservoir bag and one-way valves to ensure the inhalation of high-purity oxygen.

questions.text: Which type of study allows for the calculation of incidence rates? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

  • Incidence rates represent the number of new cases of a disease that develop in a specific population during a certain time period. Cohort studies are designed to follow a group of individuals over time to observe the development of new cases, making them ideal for calculating incidence rates.
  • This prospective longitudinal approach allows researchers to measure how many new cases occur within a defined time frame, providing accurate incidence data.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case control study: Incorrect because case control studies are retrospective and focus on comparing individuals with a condition (cases) to those without (controls) to identify risk factors, not to calculate incidence rates.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: Incorrect as cross sectional studies capture data at a single point in time, which can provide prevalence rates but not incidence rates.

 

Option D. Cross over study: Incorrect because cross over studies are experimental designs typically used to compare the effects of different treatments within the same group of participants over different periods, and are not used to calculate incidence rates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Incidence rates can be accurately calculated through cohort studies, which follow a group of individuals over time to record the occurrence of new cases.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell from a motorbike and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar urethra injury

 

  • Clinical Features: Swelling and bruising in the perineal area; difficulty passing urine; blood at the urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Surgical repair, which may involve primary anastomosis or placement of a suprapubic catheter, depending on the extent of the injury.

 

The presentation of being unable to urinate (urinary retention), the presence of blood at the urethral meatus (hematuria), and the swelling of the penis and scrotum are all indicative of a urethral injury, most likely at the bulbar segment given the described mechanism of injury.

 

The bulbar urethra is the most common site of injury in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma, such as the one described in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Membranous Urethra Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: inability to pass urine; blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic bulge, floating prostate (Vermooten sign).
  • Treatment Plan: Suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Option C. Prostatic Urethra Injury:

  • Similar to membranous urethral rupture.

 

Option D. Urinary Bladder Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: Severe lower abdominal pain, distention, inability to pass urine, signs of shock (hypotension, rapid pulse). No blood is seen at urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Immediate surgical repair to close the bladder rupture, followed by drainage of urine, and addressing any associated injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethra injury is a common site of urethral trauma, particularly in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma. The key clinical features include difficulty in urination, blood at the urethral meatus, and swelling of the penis and scrotum. The treatment often involves surgical repair or placement of a suprapubic catheter.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to TOLAC? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prior classical hysterotomy

 

Hysterotomy means incision on the uterus, prior classical hysterotomy (classical cesarean section) is an absolute contraindication to TOLAC (Trial of Labor After Cesarean). "Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision" is specifically listed as a contraindication for TOLAC. Classical cesarean scars have a significantly higher risk of rupture (2.5%) compared to lower segment transverse scars (0.5-1.0%). Classical scars are weak because they have difficult apposition of the thick muscle layer, form pockets containing blood that's replaced by fibrous tissue, and they stretch at right angles to the scar during subsequent pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prior Kerr hysterotomy: This is incorrect. Option B refers to a lower segment transverse cesarean section. Patients with "One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar" may be considered for TOLAC with proper selection criteria. Lower segment scars heal better because the thin cut margins facilitate perfect apposition, this part remains inert during healing, and the scar stretches along the line of the scar in future pregnancies.

 

Option C. Prior Kronig hysterotomy: This is incorrect. Kronig hysterectomy refers to a lower segment vertical incision. While not ideal, it doesn't fall under absolute contraindications. Low vertical incisions have a rupture risk of 0.8-1.1%, which is comparable to the low transverse incision (0.5-1.0%).

 

Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect because only the classical hysterotomy (option A) is an absolute contraindication.

 

Educational Objective: Classical cesarean scars have a significantly higher risk of rupture (2-5%) during both pregnancy and labor compared to lower segment scars (0.2-1.5%), making prior classical hysterotomy an absolute contraindication to TOLAC.

questions.text: During a health education session, people cannot understand your few technical words during the chat, and it’s a miscommunication. This is which type of barrier? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Semantic barrier


A semantic barrier, also known as a linguistic barrier, arises when there is a difference in language or when technical jargon and complex terms are used that the audience cannot understand. This leads to miscommunication because the message is not clearly conveyed. In the given scenario, the use of technical words during the health education session caused a communication breakdown because the audience did not understand those terms. This is a classic example of a semantic barrier.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cultural barrier: A cultural barrier occurs when differences in customs, beliefs, caste or religion prevent effective communication. This is not the case here as the issue was related to language and technical terms, not cultural differences.

 

Option B. Physiological barrier: Physiological barriers include physical issues like hearing difficulties or speech impairments that obstruct communication. These are not relevant to the scenario described, where language misunderstanding was the primary issue.

 

Option C. Psychological barrier: Psychological barriers stem from emotional disturbances, stress, or mental conditions that hinder effective communication. While these can affect communication, they are unrelated to the miscommunication caused by technical words in this example.

 

Educational Objective:


A semantic barrier occurs when the use of complex language, technical terms, or unfamiliar words leads to misunderstanding and miscommunication.

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

questions.text: Among the following, which bacterium is described as pleomorphic, Gram-positive small coccobacilli that exhibit tumbling motility? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Listeria monocytogenes).

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive, non-spore forming coccobacillus that exhibits a distinctive tumbling motility. This characteristic tumbling motility is temperature-dependent - present at 25°C but absent at 37°C. This differential motility pattern is a key identifying feature used in laboratory diagnosis and helps distinguish Listeria from other similar bacteria. The organism is also known for its ability to grow at refrigeration temperatures, making it a significant concern in food safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corynebacterium species - While Corynebacterium is a Gram-positive bacillus that appears pleomorphic with characteristic arrangements described as "Chinese letter" or "palisade" formations, it is non-motile. Corynebacterium species typically have metachromatic granules that stain with special dyes, but they lack the tumbling motility characteristic of Listeria.

 

Option C. Enterococcus species - Enterococcus is a Gram-positive coccus that typically appears in pairs or short chains, not as coccobacilli. Most of the species are non-motile except Enterococcus gallinarum and Enterococcus pullorum and are frequently described as having a "spectacle-shaped" appearance when arranged in pairs. They are facultative anaerobes known for their hardiness and antibiotic resistance.

 

Option D. Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae - This is a Gram-positive bacillus that can sometimes appear as short filaments. While it can cause infections in humans, particularly erysipeloid (a localized skin infection), it does not exhibit the tumbling motility characteristic of Listeria. It is primarily associated with infections acquired through occupational exposure to infected animals.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Listeria monocytogenes is uniquely characterized by its temperature-dependent tumbling motility, which serves as a critical diagnostic feature when identifying this foodborne pathogen that causes severe infections, particularly in pregnant women, newborns, and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: The most virulent form of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is seen in which type of MEN syndrome.? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MEN-2B

 

Explanation:

 

MEN-2B is associated with the most virulent and aggressive form of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MEN-2B is specifically associated with codon 918 mutations that lead to the most aggressive form of MTC, requiring thyroidectomy at a very early age (<1 year). This syndrome presents with mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and the earliest and most aggressive presentation of MTC among all the MEN syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MEN-1: This is incorrect. MEN-1 (Wermer syndrome) is not typically associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma. MEN-1 is characterized by primary hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, not MTC.

 

Option B. MEN-2A: This is incorrect. While MEN-2A (Sipple syndrome) does include medullary thyroid carcinoma as a component (~90% of cases), it is not the most virulent form. The MEN-2B variant has a more aggressive clinical course with earlier onset and more rapid progression.

 

Option D. FMTC: This is incorrect. Familial Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (FMTC) is a variant of MEN-2A but is not associated with the most aggressive form of MTC. FMTC typically has a less aggressive presentation than MTC in MEN-2B and may present with isolated MTC without other syndrome components.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

MEN-2B is characterized by the most aggressive form of medullary thyroid carcinoma, often presenting very early in life, with codon 918 mutations carrying the highest risk and requiring prophylactic thyroidectomy before 1 year of age.

questions.text: A patient has diabetes with fasting level of 140 gm/dl and PP level of 200 gm/dl. The target HbA1c to be maintained is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 7.0

 

For patients with an established diagnosis of diabetes, the target HbA1c level to be maintained is less than 7.0%. HbA1c is a measure of the average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months, and keeping it below 7.0% is considered good glycemic control for diabetic patients.

 

The given information indicates that the patient has diabetes, with a fasting blood glucose level of 140 gm/dl and a postprandial (PP) level of 200 gm/dl. These elevated glucose levels are characteristic of diabetes, and maintaining an HbA1c level below 7.0% is the recommended target to reduce the risk of diabetic complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with an established diagnosis of diabetes, the target HbA1c level to be maintained is less than 7.0% to achieve optimal glycemic control and reduce the risk of diabetic complications.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and pallor. Investigations indicated hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL, increased RDW, increased total iron binding capacity, and low ferritin. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and pallor, which are common findings in anemia. The investigations reveal a low hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL, indicating the presence of anemia. The increased red cell distribution width (RDW) suggests anisocytosis, or variation in the size of red blood cells.

 

The increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and low ferritin levels indicate a deficiency in iron stores. Additionally, the peripheral smear shows microcytosis, which means the presence of small, hypochromic red blood cells. These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia is incorrect because these patients typically have an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) due to the premature destruction of red blood cells and the release of larger, immature cells into the circulation.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic anemia is incorrect because it is characterized by the presence of large, macrocytic red blood cells, rather than the small, microcytic cells seen in this case.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia is incorrect because it is typically associated with elevated ferritin levels due to increased iron storage, whereas this patient has low ferritin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin, increased RDW, increased TIBC, low ferritin, and the presence of microcytic red blood cells on peripheral smear.

questions.text: The principle underlying vaccination is based on: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Immunologic Memory

 

Explanation:


Vaccination fundamentally relies on establishing immunologic memory in the body. When a vaccine is administered, it triggers a primary immune response that generates not only effector cells but crucially, memory B and T cells. These memory cells persist long after the primary response has subsided and enable a faster, stronger secondary immune response upon subsequent exposure to the same pathogen. This rapid recall response provides protection against the actual disease-causing organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agglutination - This is merely an antigen-antibody reaction where particulate antigens clump together in the presence of specific antibodies. While this may occur as part of immune responses following vaccination, it is not the fundamental principle underlying vaccination's protective effect.

 

Option B. Phagocytosis - This refers to the process by which cells engulf and digest foreign particles. Though phagocytosis plays a role in immune responses including those triggered by vaccines, it is not the core principle of vaccination.

 

Option D. Clonal detection - This is not a standard immunological concept. If referring to clonal selection theory, this describes how lymphocytes with receptors for specific antigens are selected to proliferate, but it's a mechanism rather than the underlying principle of vaccination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vaccination's effectiveness is rooted in immunologic memory - the ability of the adaptive immune system to "remember" previously encountered antigens and mount rapid, robust responses upon re-exposure, providing long-term protection against pathogens.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paralytic squint

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

 

Paralytic Squint:

  • Caused by paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles due to nerve damage or muscle pathology.
  • Secondary deviation (movement of the non-paralyzed eye when the paralyzed eye is fixating) is greater than primary deviation.
  • The forced duction test is negative, indicating no mechanical restriction.
  • Patients may experience diplopia and adopt a compensatory head posture to minimize double vision.

 

Additional Information

 

The squint may be either concomitant or incomitant.

• Concomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes.

• Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes.

 

 

FORCED DUCTION TEST:

 

  • Performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of extraocular muscle and that due to mechanical restriction of the ocular movements.
  • FDT is positive (resistance encountered during passive rotation) in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction.
  • FDT is negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

  • The angle of deviation is the same in all directions of gaze.
  • Commonly seen in childhood and associated with hereditary factors, uncorrected refractive errors, or perinatal injury.
  • Diplopia is typically absent because the brain suppresses the image from the deviating eye.

 

Option B.  Restrictive Squint:

  • Caused by mechanical restriction of the extraocular muscles due to conditions like thyroid eye disease, trauma, or fibrosis.
  • The forced duction test is positive, indicating resistance during passive eye movement due to mechanical restriction.
  • Diplopia is often present, and the degree of deviation varies depending on the direction of gaze.

 

Option D.  Pseudosquint:

  • An apparent squint where there is no actual misalignment of the eyes.
  • Commonly due to facial anatomical features such as epicanthal folds or a wide nasal bridge.
  • No actual deviation is present, and there are no associated symptoms like diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralytic squint is characterized by secondary deviation greater than primary deviation and a negative forced duction test, indicating the absence of mechanical restriction.

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with mutation in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PTEN

 

Cowden syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple tumor-like growths and an increased risk of certain cancers. It is associated with mutations in the PTEN gene, a tumor suppressor gene. This mutation leads to dysregulated cell growth and survival, contributing to the development of benign and malignant tumors, particularly in the breast, thyroid, and endometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. WT1: Associated with Wilms' tumor.

 

Option C. p53: Commonly mutated in various cancers but not specifically associated with Cowden syndrome.

 

Option D. Ras: Linked to a variety of cancers through different mechanisms but not directly to Cowden syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: LAP score
FISH and PCR

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 50,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

 

The clinical picture of fatigue, splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings suggest chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene, which is specific for CML.

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder that most commonly affects people in their fifth to sixth decade of life. A reciprocal (9;22) (g34;g11) translocation results in the creation of the chimeric BC-ABL gene (Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene differentiates ML from other myeloproliferative disorders and can be detected using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) .

 

Clinical characteristics:

 

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

 

Peripheral blood:

 

  • Severe leukocytosis with a leukocyte count that frequently exceeds 100,000 cells/mm, primarily composed of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Moderate normocytic normochromic anemia - Rising basophilia indicates impending blastic transformation.
  • The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • Blastic phase or blast crisis in CML satisfies the definition of acute leukemia by having more than 20% blood or marrow blasts.
  • Anemia of moderate severity - A rising basophilia is indicative of impending blastic transformation. - The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • A blast phase or blast crisis in CML meets the definition of acute leukemia by having blood or marrow blasts of more than 20%.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Used for the diagnosis of various hematologic malignancies, particularly lymphoid neoplasms. It is less specific for CML.

 

Option  B. LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase): The LAP score is typically low in CML, but this test is less specific and has largely been replaced by molecular diagnostic techniques like FISH and PCR.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: Useful for identifying and classifying hematologic malignancies based on cell surface markers but is not the most specific test for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are the most sensitive investigations for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the hallmark of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). These tests are crucial for accurate diagnosis and monitoring of CML.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Argyll Robertson Pupil is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consensual Light Reflex Normal

 

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP) is characterized by small, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not react to light - showing light-near dissociation. Both direct and consensual light reflexes are absent in ARP, while the near reflex remains intact. The consensual light reflex is absent, not normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Near Reflex Normal: The accommodation reflex is preserved in ARP. This is the key feature of light-near dissociation.

 

Option B. Direct Light Reflex Absent: This is a correct description of ARP, as the direct pupillary response to light is absent.

 

Option D. Visual Acuity Normal: Visual acuity is not affected by the pupillary abnormality in ARP.

 

Additional features of Argyll Robertson Pupil:

 

  • Bilateral involvement with small, irregular pupils
  • Pupils dilate poorly with mydriatics
  • Most commonly seen in tertiary neurosyphilis
  • Can also occur in diabetes, Wernicke's encephalopathy, and midbrain tumors
  • Caused by a lesion in the pretectal area of the midbrain

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Argyll Robertson Pupil shows complete light-near dissociation with absence of both direct and consensual light reflexes, while accommodation (near) reflex is preserved.

questions.text: A patient presents with a combination of Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis. Upon further examination, it is discovered that the individual has a diet deficient in a specific nutrient. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin deficiency

 

Explanation:
